Review Text: We dropped into Glenloch for a quick look at tea production and some lunch.  We noticed other visitors receiving guided tours but nobody approached us so we just took a look around ourselves.  It's a bit like stepping back in time for anyone who works in modern manufacturing with a lot of manual labour interspersed with some very old machines. Lunch was quite good although our waiter didn't seem all that interested in serving us.  I recommend the Nasi Goreng. We bought some tea from the extensive range in their tourist shop which is worth a visit as you can smell and/or taste most of the teas available.

The driver insisted to bring us here, so we gave this a chance. We tried 3 teas, which I can only describe as ranging from cardboard to floor dust flavour notes. I asked some questions about tea, none of which they were able to answer, for example question ‚Äòwhat variety of white tea is this?‚Äô Answer ‚Äòwhite tea‚Äô. Thank you. At the end they force you to go the shop and then they get very pushy and annoying. Unsurprisingly one then learns that their workers are very poorly paid which raises all sorts of ethical questions. Absolutely avoid.
Interesting visit, we were able to taste different teas. The staff speaks French which made it easier to understand the explanations. The store offers all varieties of teas produced on site.

A big drawback for us was that it was the ‚ÄúFull-Moon‚Äù holiday and the workers were not in the fields or in the factory.  The tour still showed the tea drying and where the workers would be. We had a tea tasting. Be sure to ask for milk and sugar if you want it, because it is not automatically offered. It is easy to spend lots of money on tea to take home.  Caveat Emptor

Its a very informative tour, I have learned new things about Tea. I just a had hard time understanding the accent of the Guide and It will be a bit boring if your really not into the TEA because its a bit lengthy because you will literally go around the whole factory.. But basically the tour was nice, the hostess that guided us and assisted us was very nice. There will also be a free tasting of different teas so that you would have an idea if ever you would purchase some. You can also visit/walk through their plantation and they have very nice view of the mountains. (the whole tour was free of charge)

We absolutely loved our experience at Glenloch Tea Estate. The tea tour was truly unforgettable, thanks to our knowledgeable guide who explained every step of tea-making with so much detail and passion. It was fascinating to see the skill, time, and dedication that go into producing each cup of tea. A highlight was dressing up in traditional tea-picking attire and trying to fill a basket ourselves‚Äîit was much harder than it looked but so much fun! And the Golden Flush tea we tried? Simply elite. We‚Äôre hooked and will only be drinking this from now on!
I was able to see and learn about how Tea leaves are picked, sorted, how stems and other waste is removed, and what part of the tea is used in the brew.

We were a little time pressed and this suited us down to the ground. It got us into the tea country quickly enough from Kandy (a smidgen over an hour). We got a bit of the view of tea-country, and a fifteen minute tour of a tea factory. I'd like to have spent more time - they could perhaps beef up the tour but it was well worth it. I wish I'd been there when the factory was busier but neither of us regretted this visit.
Tea color and taste is very bad after adding a spoonful of Milk. That is why they don't keep even milk powder at the tasting facility.

If you are a tea lover then this will be a tour for you! This is a small working tea factory and you see the whole process of how the tea gets from the bush to your cup! We had a lovely guide to show us around. There was a free cup of tea at the end of the tour which we had on a verandah overlooking the beautiful tea plantations. There is also a small shop where you can purchase tea produced at the factory.

We had a short, but informative tour which we found extremely interesting. This plantation is set in a stunning setting. We had fun tasting various teas and of course, being British, we bought a good range home for our home and for gifts. Lovely tea I hasten to add.

We stopped here on the way to Nuwara. We found the factory tour really interesting and although it was busy our guide really took the time with us. There is a shop where we bought tea but didn't in any way feel obligated like some attractions (this was welcome) keep up the good work.
We got a nice tour on the plantage en fabric with friendly staff. Not pushy at all to buy anything. It's worth seeing also with kids.

Review Title: Authentic private tours around a fascinating factory
Review Text: This tea factory hasn't got a lot of publicity but is excellent.  we had our own guide just for the 2 of us - and the tour was fascinating.  Some very old machinery both from Scotland and England and incredibly preserved.  Fascinating tour and then we got to taste tea and pick the tea with the baskets on heads - super tour

Most of the bags are either split or they split when stirring in the cup. You end up with a heap of tea leaf bits at the bottom of your cuppa. A complete waste of money and so disappointing after an enjoyable tour.
We have visited several tea factories. This one may not have the most informative guided tours but they sell organic tea. I don‚Äôt mind paying some Rupees more for superior quality.
Always a pleasure to visit a tea factory, and learn their manufacturing process. Make sure you visit when you are around this place.

Our driver took us to the Glenloch tea factory on a day trip through Ramboda and into the mountains towards NuwaraEliya. We took a stroll up the hill to see the tea pickers and on the way down two children came to 'chat' to us. Their English was good, but scripted- asking where we were from and welcoming us to Sri Lanka with a handshake. They said they were 12 years old. As we reached halfway back down the hill they started hassling us for money. This was not unexpected, but it saddened me. They should be at school, but obviously rich tourists offer more prospects to them and their family. We didn't give them anything as doing so would only reinforce this practice. Our tour guide was very friendly and answered all of our questions. However, when we reached the 2nd machine where they 'swill' the leaves, one of the workers started to get really angry and was shouting and being pretty abusive to our guide. There is obviously a problem here that they try to cover up, but it was really unpleasant to watch. The tour was quick and the tea at the end seemed good (I tried green and black). There was no pressure for tips or to buy, although I felt obliged to do both. Let's hope the tea lives up to its high price tag once I get it home! Oh and by the way- avoid the toilet unless you are really desperate- awful and door didn't even close!

My husband and I were originally going to go to another plantation which we found online but our driver recommend Glenloch Tea factory and we are pleased he did take us here ! We were given a free tour into the factory by a lovely woman who spoke perfect English . She was friendly and knowledgeable about tea . The factory was very interesting as you saw first hand the process of the tea . Very interesting . Afterwards my husband had lunch there with the free tea they served us . Good tea , mediocre lunch but you do not expect great food at a plantation . Good tea ! We bought some tea as. souvenir. We did not need to go see other tea plantations after we had seen this one . Worth a visit if you are in the area !

We liked the tour very much and was interesting to see how tea is being made. At the end you go through a shop. We wanted to buy white tea and we were told that it is not possible to buy it at the supermarket or local shop other than this shop. This was not true. We paid 4 time the cost in the supermarket!

We had lunch at its restaurant. The restaurant is under renovation, and so it is very dusty. Food is expensive, cold and not authentic. If possible, I will not recommend anyone to dine there. In contrast, the factory tour is much more pleasant. Our tour guide is really friendly and patiently explained all of our questions. You may request more than one cup of tea if you are preparing to buy some. The factory was built 150 years ago, worth visiting.

We were there last December. We stopped over for lunch which was not good at all. We had biryani which was plain yellow rice and a separately fried chicken ... The veg menu was catastrophic as well as it was tasteless. The waiters are very slow but with good intentions. The visit to the tea factory was done in a noisy environment and we could not hear properly the lady who guided us. The tea tasting was the only solace though.

We had a brief visit to this tea factory, as our driver/guide took us there on the way from our visit to Pinnawala Elephant Orphanage to our next destination in Colombo. Really pleased we went. Had a full tour of the factory, during which we were told about the types of tea leaf, shown how it's dried and sorted into different grades before being ground down and packed. Followed then by a few cups of different types of tea, including the premium silver tips tea. A worthwhile visit and great insight into tea making. And no charge, other than a discretionary tip for the guide.

There was a tea factory tour where the lady took us into the production area and explained to us step by step on how tea is manufactured from tea leaves. She was answering our questions along the way w/o being disinterested. You also get a complimentary cup of tea at the end of the tour and may choose to purchase tea from the cafe itself to bring back home with you.

Nice place. will had a a great tour. show and explain everything in detail about Tea making process. from plant to cup of tea. It was really interesting to see the process from beginning to end. Thanks

The guide was very friendly and fluent. The location is breathtaking. I would have preferred to walk around the tea plantation for a longer period. Reasonable prices though I expected to find cheaper offers.

Definitely worth a visit and really interesting to see the process. We tasted the equivalent to English breakfast. It was nice although our tour guide seemed to be impatient waiting right next to us until we had drank our tea so felt rushed. Didn't buy in the shop as v.expensive but tipped our guide.

Don‚Äôt waste your time coming here, you‚Äôll leave disappointed.  Our female guide had no interest whatsoever in talking & showing us the factory.  Whole tour took less than 10 minutes. We also made the mistake of eating lunch here.  The five of us all concurred, that it was the worst meal & service in our 8 days in Sri Lanka.  We had the stir fried beef, devilled chicken, biriyani rice, fish & chips (photo below) & spaghetti. We told our driver of our terrible experience & he said ‚Äúthey just get so busy they have to rush‚Äù. Well.... that‚Äôs not good enough if they want us to spend our hard earned cash with them! Do yourself a favour & avoid this place! In general Sri Lanka has a long way to come in order to reach the level & expertise of service both Thailand & Bali provide to westerners.

We were given a quick tour of the factory. It was interesting to find out how tea is processed. We saw all the machines,etc. Tried only 2 different types of tea, they were ok. They have a shop where you're u can purchase tea. It would have been nice to go and see the workers picking the tea in the fields.

Visited Glenloch as part of a 1 day organised tour. Tour of Tea factory and the process was very interesting. The tour guide was very friendly and informative and answered any questions. There was a tea tasting session at the end of the tour followed by the opportunity to purchase any of the tasted teas to "take home". Very interesting, especially for any tea drinkers out there.

Glenloch was magical. We were doing a road trip with tents around Sri Lanka and stumbled across Glenloch whilst trying to find somewhere to pitch out tents as the sun was coming down. The lovely owner let scamp in his garden, whilst we had a private function going on in the guesthouse. Not only that but they provided power, tea, breakfast etc  - they could not have been more hospitable if they tried, and the best thing is that they didn't expect or ask for any money from us. Of course we offered it but they did not seem to expect it. It was the highlight of my trip, the view was stunning, food delicious, and experience unforgettable. Thank you Glenloch!

Beautiful nice girl guided us through the whole process of making tea. Very interesting experience to see and smell. Not any easy from the harvest to the final product. And although I am not a particular tea lover I have to say that the taste of the provided sample was simply great and definitely from time to time I have tea instead of coffee.

we visited today. I knew that after the tour and explanation they will give tea to drink and then the sales pitch. The green tea to taste was good. I decided to buy their Golden flush which is their own premium brand. I paid 4000 LKR for 50 tea bags. Having read another review that most tea bags had only dust, I tried to try it out in my room as I am staying in Nuwara Eliya today. The tea is not dust but leaves in a pyramid bag (the stronger variety). The tea did taste good with no strong after taste. Good to drink without milk or with just a little bit. I am sure the price will not be this high (¬£20) if it is not for foreigners. But this is a trend I have seen in this first visit to SL.

As with most of these things, our Virgin Holidays tour guide stopped us here, and I'm sure they all get a lovely cut. The tour was interesting enough, though not that informative as the guide's English wasn't amazing. The "complimentary" tea was a good redbush. The shop was badly laid out but the pricing was clear and there was no hard sell. The tea was cheaper than it would be in the UK, but again I'm sure it's double what it would cost elsewhere. But at ¬£10 for three boxes it isn't a scam, just a bit of a tourist trap. Although as we were there a bus load of local schoolkids arrived for a tour, so it can't be all that bad. It was a welcome cup of tea and a walk on the long drive from Negombo to Kandy, but not worth going out of your way for. And it's overpriced, but ¬£3.50 in the grand scheme of things isn't worth fretting over
Very interesting Tour on the tea factory. Friendly staff and ended the Tour with tea and cake. Best tea ever...

A tourist trap.  One is quickly shown around the rather smallish factory.  Complimentary tea and then ushered to a rather pricy factory store.  Where products are sold at double the price.  I will suggest one goes there sees the factory and not buy anything.  Also I think the driver or tour operator gets a cut here.  Also the packaging does not have manufacturing date or product details.

Tea has always been a bit mysterious in my part of the world. This tour showed all the stages of production and explained how different teas are handled. There was plenty of time to ramble around the plantation as well. Workers eager to pose to earn extra tips. Interesting that they asked for tips to be put in a box to share among all the workers instead of just to the guides. Seems like a good move. Nice cup of tea at the end and mercifully none of the usual sales pressure. Really enjoyed it. My only regret is that the machinery was so noisy that I missed a lot of the commentary.

It's always interesting to see how stuff is made (and not just on Discovery Channel)... They show you the   Very basic and traditional way tea is made!  And then you can try it all... And buy whatever you want.  Best gifts you can take out of Sri Lanka.

Did this on our way back from Kandy to Bentota. Not a great tea drinker myself, but my wife wanted to visit a tea plantation. After stopping on the road to see a tea picker picking the shoots, she quickly moved the car to give these to my wife, but in turn expected some Rupees. The tour was quick, reasonably informative, but the guide spoke too fast and was difficult to catch all that she was saying. After the tour we got to sample some tea, and inevitably was led into the shop where my wife purchased, yes, you guessed it, some tea!! Was OK, but could have been a whole lot better.

Visited this tea plantation,factory interesting how they produce the tea .Restaurant meal they seemed to be in a hurry asking me before I'd finished if I wanted anything else .Toasted ham & cheese sandwich disappointing.
You can check tea plantation, processing at one glance with surrounding awesome natural beauty. verity of teas are available to buy.
Our driver made a stop here on the our way up to our hotel. enjoyed good tea. staff were informative. Made some purchases of green and black tea. enjoying it.

We enjoyed the tour of the factory and we ate lunch at the onsite restaurant (average and expensive for Sri Lanka). We had a nice lady taking us around but felt the tour was very short, we were then led to a room to sample the tea's on offer (had really bad heartburn after) and were then let into the shop to try and sell us some tea. We didn't buy anything but got some nice photos with the staff.

Really interesting tour of the factory to see how Tea is made. Super friendly staff whose English was perfect making it a very engaging tour for us. Great to sample the different teas and purchase some too. Lovely to get the opportunity to pick some tea too

Lovely spot, but it might depend which guide you get at this place. Mine was smiley and pleasant but rushed me through the tea factory, hardly explained anything, had no opportunity to pick tea, and was overly eager to "help" me purchase tea in the shop. I had to speak quite firmly to her to get her to back off. Also, why doesn't anyone mention the tea pickers themselves? They are the backbone of the industry, as I understand it. Generally low income Tamil women. The guide acted as though they didn't exist and failed to point out the tip box in the factory for the pickers. But she was certainly angling for her own tip. I'd try another place next time.

Our driver took us here as an unexpected "treat". Very interesting to see what it take to make something that we wll take for granted. The process is very dusty and noisy, but not a sign of masks or ear defenders - a union would have a field day here! Well worth a visit with camera to capture the various stages and look forward to a free cup of tea at the end of the tour.

We were taken through the tea making process of making black tea and told about white and green tea. The explanations were quite mechanical rather than related with enthusiasm. We were given English breakfast tea to taste. I would have preferred to walk around the actual tea plantations before getting to the factory. Worth a look if you didn‚Äôt see one before.

Everyday we consume many cups but never gave a thought of how we manage to get into teabags. Well the wait is over. A brief introduction of how things are managed and kept and packaged are shown and told. Once you know the details, you will learn to enjoy that cup of tea more than ever. The tour educational. Sri Lanka is known for Teas. So find one which you enjoy most :-)

I didn't visit this place. A friend did and bought a box of tea for us back home as gift. It had a suspicious smell and tasted awful, sour, kind of reminded me of the smell of peel of lychee. It appeared to us that it wasn't just some cheap tea; instead, something was really wrong with it. One of us started to feel weird in the stomach after drinking it. So you can probably visit this place again, but we don't recommend buying tea from them.

On the way nuwara eliya great stop ever for lunch with excellent nasi goren and other set menu , very hard to find descent food in this area And also the free tour of factory is informative and free cup of tea is also gr8 There is a shop and No pressure to buy

The Glenloch teafactory gives you a very insight in how tea is processed. You visit all parts of the plant, can touch the tea (interesting from a food safety point of view..) and see how the machines and the workers work. The guide we had hardly was able to explain the process, so it is advisable you have some processing knowledge yourself
Very interesting and cognitively ‚òùüèª We saw the process of working with tea. We walked near tea plantation , tried different tipes of tea. Very cool üòé
Glenloch tea tree plantation was a lovely and  peaceful. The scenic view was  breathtaking, lush and full of tea plants and other greenery.

Having been driven up into the highlands of sri lanka by ranjan we stopped at glenloch .this is where there are more than just black and green tea silver and gold are now added to the list.all are made from the top leaves silver and gold are from the youngest and smallest leaves and along with green are not fermemted Tea came to sri lanka when a scots man borrowed some tea plants from china the rest is history

It was super interesting to get an insight into the making of tee! Our guide Ms. Devika was amazing she answered all of our questions and explained everything very well we couldn‚Äôt have had a better guide! She also spoke very good English as well as German which was very helpful :) Overall a very nice place to stop for a visits if you‚Äôre interested in Tee you can taste different tees as well !

As I have only ever visited one( this) tea factory I really can't say how good it is in comparison to others. What I can say is that we really enjoyed it. Didn't take too long, say the process from start to finish, saw the the classic scene of the tea pickers at work, old but functioning machines drying sorting and rolling the leaves. Very informative guide and a great cuppa to finish it off overlooking the amazing hills. Really recommend this place for a visit

Our guide recommended breaking up our journey from Nuwara Eliya to Kandy by stopping at this tea factory (we'd passed many on our way - this was one of the last). We declined to take the tour as we've been fortunate enough to go around a tea factory whilst in the Seychelles and we were were aware that the processing area would be hot! We went into the shop area (which had a good selection of teas) and admired the views from the balcony. We were still offered a free cup of tea, despite not doing the tour. As bird watchers we also noted a few Hill Swallows, a notable species having a very limited distribution in Sri Lanka and south west India.

Even though there were tour buses, the two of us got our own private tour.  The girl did a good job explaining things, and was able to answer our questions. It's in a beautiful area, and you can see beautiful views while you sit and enjoy the free cup of tea after the tour. There is a lot of tea to purchase, and your guide will help you but won't be pushy.

Myself and 16 travel companions dropped in at this Tea Plantation and Factory on the way from Kandy to Yala. It proved a welcome and informative rest stop. A young woman showed us around the factory floors, providing us with valuable descriptions of the tea manufacturing process from cultivation and picking to how teas are selected and packaged. It was actually quite absorbing. We finally enjoyed cups of Broken Orange Peko Fannings tea, about the best, and made our purchases. The views from the tea house and shop are quite stunning! This was one if those felicitous stops we were glad to have made; I recommend this Tea Factory heartily.

I visited Glenloch with my partner during our stay in Sri Lanka. Our guide was kind and showed us the main part of the factory - nothing in depth but good enough. We did taste the different teas they have to offer and they were really tasty. It was good to learn a bit more but nothing was exceptional - at the end of he day the main goal is to sell you overpriced items!
Well organized and informative. Our guide was well informed, friendly and helpful. If you're a tea drinker/lover I'd definitely recommend a visit

Our driver/guide made sure that we didn't miss to visit this Tea Factory. It was busy with tourists, our guide walked us through the whole process with only some of the machines working in about 20 minutes. This young lady guide was charming but her English accent was very difficult for us to understand. At the end of the factory tour, we were directed to the Gift Shop Area and offered a complimentary cup of tea. Great tea along with a very good selection of teas to buy! The Management would do well to computerize the Billing System and also pay attention to the washrooms which require not only to be upgraded but also better maintained.

We really enjoyed our tour of the Glenloch Tea Factory. Our guide was very knowledgable. One tip though - if any of the factory workers offer to pose in a photo they will expect to be paid (we had only just arrived and had no idea what was a reasonable tip amount - the 20 rupees we gave was not well received).

I visited Glenloch Tea Factory. It was a good experience to understand how tea is manufactured. Factory Engineer and Supervisor Mrs. Jeevani has demonstrated the complete tea manufacturing process excellently. From welcoming to explaining process and equipments and tea products with sample tastes, it was a wonderful experience. Thank you very much to all the staff!!

Second Tea Factory visit and arguably the better one, our guide was superb, very informative, showed us all around and explained very well the different processes. We sampled the different teas in their tea shop and purchased some of the blends to take home. We were also put to work picking tea on their plantation which was an experience - I‚Äôm not very good!

Our driver took us to this factory. A lot of other buses here. The guide we received was very uninspired and just did the tour as quick as possible. The factory was quite dark and the machines were not running when we were there. We tasted some tea after the tour. Nothing special but we bought some packages of vanilla tea.

If your visiting Nuwara Eliya then this place has got to be a place you visit. It gives a great insight into the countries tea industry plus you can taste the tea for yourself. We all enjoyed out stop here they have a good car park and you can see the full tea production process not to mention the spectacular views of the surrounding tea country

Called in here for the factory tour and was amazed at how genuinely historically it has been kept. Very noisy so it was difficult to hear what the charming guide was saying but even so very worthwhile. Nice cup of tea at the end and no pressure to buy any products.

We stopped in this tea factory where we discovered how the tea is made from the leaf. Good explanations, nice place and good tea. We enjoyed our visit and even if buying tea here is certainly most expensive than in super markets or other places, it is still a pleasure and a good memory.
I dear friend visited Sri Lanka and brought back a tin of Glenloch orange pekoe Best brightest flavourI have found in a lifetime of tea sampling

The tea factory is like any other you will visit, however, the taste of the their brew was superb. After a round of the factory, they will give you taste of their popular (not their best) brew, which most will abviously like.  I had to ask for tasting their different teas, which my host readily agreed to.  I must confess I am a tea lover and have a weak point for Silver Tips which I found was up to mark and readily purchased two packs - one for myself and one for a friend who too is a tea connoisseur.  Worth a visit I will say.

Along the winding drive through the mountains and tea plantations, we stopped at Glenloch Tea Factory. It was really interesting and our guide was knowledgeable and to the point which we liked. After the tour we enjoyed a cup of tea on the balcony and took in the beautiful views before hitting the road again.

Being Indian (now living in america) we know the importance of Tea. A cup of tea in the morning gives a kick start to the life. We had detailed view of the Factory and could see how tea is processed from leaf to packed bags. It was interesting and the factory staff was eager to explain whatever we asked for. The restaurant of the Factory was updated with all variety of tea manufactured here. I bought two packs for the house in USA.We visited this factory during our visit to Sri Lanka in Dec.2012.We were on our way to Nuwara Eliya when we took a break here.

You do feel a little bit like you are on a conveyer belt here yourself as there are tours starting every few minutes. They only last around 15 minutes and then you are taken to try the tea. The tea sold in the shop is not the cheapest, but then you wouldn't expect it to be. The views from the top of here across the valley are lovely.

Interesting quick tour and cup of tea. Looks like nothing has changed in 150 years! I'm not a tea consumer but to me it tasted like everyday supermarket tea.  The was no big pressure to buy.  Left a tip in the box provided. They could have made a nice presentation of sampling but didn't bother.  Lame.

We didn't know anything about tea so found this was very informative and fascinating. Felt like our tour girl was in a huge hurry to finish the tour though. Disappointing that the tour was only the factory not the fields too. Haven't tried it yet but bought the strongest tea at 1200 LKR for 400 grams.
We had an interest and informative tour of the tea factory followed by a tea tasting and the opportunity to buy some tea from the gift shop. Good activity for all ages.

Nice tour conducted by a lady who explained it thoroughly and well on how teas are planted, processed, the various grade and the best way to drink it:).  The tour finished off with sample of teas from the plantations and as usual like many other tourist places, head to the shop - they are reasonably priced and its something that you probably cant get back home!    Nice day out in a nice cool weather.   I really enjoyed it.
Look before you eat anything from the restaurant . I found this in my rice on  11 th December 2017 & check your glass before drinking anything .
This tour was recomended by our driver but the tour itself was perfunctory, around 10 minutes and they seemed more keen to get us into the shop. The guide herself did not seem overly interested.
Nice informative tour from plucking to processing! Tea tasting included! Beautiful tasting room and gift shop!

We had a great time at Glenloch. It was very interesting to see how the tea is processed and even better to enjoy a nice cup afterwards. The view is breathtaking and the Tea is excellent. You will find a great cup here.

Visit to the Glenloch Tea Factory on the way to Nuwara Eliya was my second visit to a tea factory after the one i visited in Munnar. We were taken around and introduced to the process of tea making starting from plucking to the final product which makes its way to our home. The factory is very neat and it takes about 15 mins to see all the process involved in making some of the finest black tea in the world in terms of its distinct flavor, aroma, and strength. We were treated to a cup of black tea and what stood out was the wonderful aroma. There is a shop from where you can purchase a variety of tea. If you happen to visit Nuwara Eliya, do visit any of the tea factories. It hardly takes a hour and it is not every day you can see your favorite tea processed in front of your eye.

I would have given this 4 stars if it wasn't for the relatively hard sell at the end of our tour with tea prices which are ridiculously high.  ¬£4.00 for a small box of loose Earl Grey Tea when it costs less than ¬£1.00 at Cargills is simply too steep. As to the museum, our whole family enjoyed learning about tea and seeing the old British machinery from the 19th century.  It was easy to imagine the workings of the factory and it was an informative trip down memory lane.  I think the factory tour is free but the museum cost ¬£2.50 to get in.  As Tea is part of the Sri Lankan culture now, a visit to some kind of museum should really be on your agenda.  Not sure if this is the best one but it certainly gives you a good insight into the differences of green/black teas and what manufacturing processes are used.

We found the Heritage Tea Plantations beautiful as we were driving through the tea country from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya. Our driver stopped at Glenloch Tea Factory to show us how tea is being dried and packed to be ready for a drink. We visited the tea factory late afternoon, so we could not see the whole process. In spite of this, our guide was very nice and he explained everything while he was taking us round. It was so interesting! We got a sample cup of tea to taste their product and then we could buy tea in the shop. We enjoyed our visit here and brought a few boxes of their nice tea home!

It is touristy but not a tourist trap. It is well worth a visit - you get a tour of the factory and insight as to how the process is from picking the tea to selling it. And there is a shop where you can buy a variety of Glenloch tea - We bought a lot and have not been dissappointed, the tea is great, nice flavour.

We stopped by on the off chance of a tour and were pleased to find that it wasn‚Äôt too busy. The tour guide took her time with us, explaining each step of the process in English. Then we had the chance to sample the teas and walk around the shop before going outside to pluck tea ourselves. They also offered our driver a cup while he waited for us. The kids (12 and 9) enjoyed it too!

We made a brief stop at the Glenloch Tea Factory as part of our visit to the Nuwara Eliya tea highlands. We had a very informative tour and explanation of the tea production process, and saw some interesting old machinery from the colonial days still in use! The different types and gradings of tea were explained (i now know exactly what is meant by broken orange pekoe) and then we sat down to taste some free samples (NB: cake costs extra). Afterwards, it was on to the gift shop which sold the finished product at reasonable prices. As I had always suspected (and the visit confirmed) the tea we use in the West in our teabags really is called "dust"!....

On our trip around Sri Lanka we stop among many places here, our guide set us up with a guide a the factory that went trough all the steps of tea making. It was really interesting, and more so if we actually could hear what she said all the time. The noice was a bit to load as the tour was in the actual factory. But maybe she could have spoken up a bit, we had to stay really close and pay attention to hear the main parts at least. After we tasted the different teas and bought quite much to family and friends.
Worst experience. Solid marketing but terrible results back home. Red Label is much more better than this Glenloch. One must ask for tasting after adding a bit of milk.

Good free tour of working tea factory with original 100 year old + machines. With a nice hot cuppa at the end. Anyone slightly interested in Engineering or manufacturing will enjoy this. I actually enjoyed this more than the temple of the tooth.

Nothing to see equipment wise that was actually working other than one large tray of drying tea leaves. Staff were bored and not really interested in anything apart from chatting to each other. Only decent bit was tasting 4 of their teas. Good selection of teas on offer but they were expensive

We visited the tea factory at the moment where 2 busses arrived. Our guide was in a hurry because of these busses. We got a lot of information about the proces from leave to tea... with a lot of noise it was dificult to folluw the explanation, such a pitty. We had a tea taste at the end and a big shop where you can buy a lot of different tea .

Lovely place that has opened it doors for the public to see how tea leaves are collected and processed. They are generous to share the process and you can taste tea before you decide which you will buy. The lady serving the tea was very friendly and was encouraging me to try the different teas and made the effort to serve me. The tea has a very fresh aroma and refreshing. Tried the white tea for the first time; it gives good complexion, I am told. Would have preferred the commentary from someone who is passionate about the work than someone who just wants to get the job done with.

I visited The Glenloch Tea factory with my family. The tour was very interesting and the guide excellent. We bought 8 packs of three kinds of tea to take back to The UK with us‚Ä¶what an idea gift we thought! We also bought some tea for ourselves. However, when we tried to drink the tea after returning home it was unpalatable. The Ginger tea for instance tasted of dish-water, quite disgusting. The friends who we gave the tea as gifts were, without exception, in agreement. I apologised to them. Maybe we bought a bad batch? So I emailed The Glenloch Tea Company and reported what, when and how it tasted. They didn‚Äôt answer let alone acknowledge. I checked the email address on their site several times and it was correct. I waited. Two weeks later I wrote again. No response. Two weeks again and I wrote now three weeks on and not even the courtesy of acknowledgement, a reply or even better an apology! I now believe that they must have so many complaints that they just don‚Äôt bother to answer. Therefore I would most certainly choose one of the other plantations to visit but if your guide insists that you visit The Glenloch Tea Factory enjoy the tour but be strongly advised NOT to purchase any tea in their shop.

We decided to stop at Glenloch for our tea experience rather than the many other processers around Nuwara Eliya as photos of the factory are permitted, as well as due to the fact it was on the way to the town from Kandy. We arrived to be welcomed by a member of staff who would take us around the factory. Tours are free but visitors are invited to give tips at the end which are distrubuted among all staff. We started our tour seeing the picked leaves being sorted. You are then taken through the whole processing process, from drying, through to cutting, to packing. It was a fascinating insight into a product that so many people enjoy. None of it is staged (although there is some now redundant equipment around to help explain how things were done before some parts of the process were mechanised) so you are seeing tea which well end up in your tea back home being processed. At the end of the tour you are invited to try some of the teas and of course purchase some if you wish.  You can also wander around outside and see people picking tea. Definitely worth a stop if you are travelling between Kandy and Nuwara Eliya: its a good way to stretch the legs.

Not only are the views breathtakingly beautiful, but the tea served here was delicious! Our guide took us around the factory and allowed us time to peruse before moving on to the next section. Our guide spoke excellent English and answered any questions we had. After the tour, we were served complimentary tea of each variety that the factory sold. My personal favourite being the white silver tip tea. While we were tasting our guide explained the health benefits if each. On site they had a chocoletier stand, and these chocolates were also delicious. Although compared to most places you visit in Sri Lanka, the tea that they sold was more expensive than any where else we had visited. The price is 100% worth it! my partner and I purchased both the golden flush, BOPF, BOP and silver tip tea, and all are fantastic. Tea picking! Once we had finished in the tea factory's resturaunt, we had an opportunity to pick tea from one of the Glenloch tea gardens. All in all a very enjoyable experience and if i were ever in Sri Lanka again I would definitely re-visit.

visited as part of a trip to Kandy. Our factory guide was very informative and explained everything clearly. I was delighted to see machinery made in the UK and Ireland 100yrs ago still working. The tasting was also an experience, tasted tea I've never tried before. I've read comments about the tea not tasting the same at home. The main reason for this is the water not the quality of the tea.

Personalized Tea Factory Tour was interesting and free.  Tried tea samples and purchased some excellent tea.  Also, had flavored teas.  Our guide stopped here on way to Sigirlya Rock Temple.  Nice to stop and visit by minivan since the other half of our Tea Plantation Tour was taking the Train and our guide picking us up halfway due to time limitations.

A quick and free tour it was good to see and learn more about the tea and different types and sizes giving different flavours. Free tea tasting and cup of tea.  The tea shop is how they make their money but it was not madly over priced and did not feel pressured. The views are worth the stop alone.

After being to Tea Factories in Sri Lanka in the past, I had told the driver not to bother as my experience is that you gain very little knowledge and are ushered as quick as possible to the shop to try a Luke warm cup of tea and then harassed until you give up and buy a packet of tea. However the guide assured me this one was different and I have to say it was. There was a very friendly guide who showed us around and gave a very informative lecture with props on the process. Afterwards we were offered tea and were in no way harassed to buy tea. Actually the reception in the tea shop was so pleasant I ended up buying tea! Price was very reasonable as well. Certainly worth a visit if you want to visit a tea factory. Rather noticeable were the empty car parks of factories I had visited before!

Our Guide arranged a visit to this factory because we wanted to discover the Ceylon tea plantations. Delighted by our visit: nights visited the factory and the processes, tasted the different teas made and even learned how to pick. Very rewarding. Our hostess was charming. We also bought some boxes of good teas as a souvenir ‚ù§Ô∏è

Glenloch tea factory is smaller than some others, and thus attracts somewhat less tourists. The excursion was quite short, skipping the growing of tea bushes and getting directly to processing tea leafs. The guide was very nice and friendly, and even though she offered not much information herself, she was ready to answer as many additional questions as we asked. After the excursion was a short tasting of tea (good), and a shop with quite a good selection. Upon trying purchased tea at home, I can say I'm not disappointed at all.

This was an interesting little tour which shows the process of making tea. We found it quite informational, and you get to sample the tea at end. There's a little restaurant you can eat there with good views.

Tour if the tea factory was good and very informative, especially considering I know nothing of the history of tea. I was impressed with what I learned and interested with what they showed me. I had a chance to try several teas afterwards and yes, there was an opportunity to buy, although there was no pressure. This place is worth the visit. Purchased two boxes of tea for 20,000 rupees $20

The lady who provided the tour was very knowledgeable and warm, she had excellent spoken English and the tour was interesting and not too long or short. The shop was quite expensive at the end but made for nice browsing. Great views of the plantation area and a trip worth making if you are in the area

Visited this tea plantation on route from Kandy. Our guide was knowledgable and you can walk through the factory and get a good feel of the process. We visited MacWoods after here, and found Glenloch offered us a 'small' plantation feeling, whereas in MacWoods, it was a bit more of a tour round their museum.

A short but informative trip round this small tea factory. Some of the machinery processing the tea was very old (not operational when we visited) An opportunity to learn about the variety of teas and how they are produced. A good taster session. We bought a load and I am still enjoying it. Many thanks.

We went on 2 tea tours, this one and Pedro - go and do the Pedro tour and refuse the invitation to go here unless you really want to take photos inside (as they're banned on the Pedro tour). Our guide processed us through the tour and told us the rolling machine was a cutter then offered us a cup of tea but seemed agitated when we actually wanted to drink it - she eventually (after about 5 minutes) exclaimed that she was going to leave to take another tour which was a relief but instead remained awkwardly until my wife gave in and we left our tea and went to the shop to buy something and be released from our shadow. As per many of these places, you're pressurised into buying at overinflated prices and if you're on a tour and trusting your guide you often end up falsely believing that the prices are actually normal or that you may not have a better chance to buy tea! The tea prices are determined by where you're from so if you can convince them you live in an ex-pat community in Galle then you may be onto a better deal? I dread to think how much less I could have paid buying premium Ceylon tea in the UK. Pedro was a nicer experience and there was no pressure - actually they didn't even bother to tell us there was a shop where we could buy souvenirs etc. It was 200 rupees for the tour but worth every one of the 100ish pennies that represents.

Free to enter, this working tea factory offers you an informative tour during which you can take photos and video and follow up with a free cup of tea.  We bought some tea back to the UK with us and it is delicious!

We had a well rehearsed but very interesting explanation of the tea leaf production process, followed by complimentary tea tasting. Photos of the machinery were allowed. Then we were ushered into the shop and closely followed/guided around with some pressure to purchase. However, we both enjoyed the whole experience and felt that we learned something new about tea.

We had a very good tour of the factory. Our driver dropped us off at the factory and our guide gave us a detailed description of the process, let us take photographs and he also took some excellent photographs of us. The guide also took us to the edge of the plantation for further photographs, then off to the cafe for a selection of the different complimentary teas. The guide was excellent and looked after us during the time, I think the tip helped, but he was very helpful and we enjoyed the trip.

Our driver brought us to this tea factory as I told him I was obsessed with tea. The visit to the tea factory was interesting. The lady walked us through to the entire process and we were lucky enough to see the huge machines in actions. She explained the process briefly and showed us the different types of tea they made. The overall tour took about 10 - 15 minutes. Photography is allowed here, unlike other places which I have read. You can then proceed to the store and purchase some tea - quite reasonable prices (SGD 10 for three large packets). We had lunch here as well. The fried chicken briyani was really good! And view during lunch is amazing as well.

Tour and tea tasting are free.  tour is ok but not view of plantation, and not testing except one cup of tea so  tea tasting is a disappointment. If you want to buy tea, this is the place to be ripped off. A total no go.. it's a surprise how they are still on business. If your tour is taking you there, avoid shopping! after visit they send you directly to the shop... there is better place to go.

Review Title: If you get to visit the estate might be worth it. Else avoid.
Review Text: We reached there a bit late, around there closing time. The lady who escorted us gave all the info about the working of the factory. Gave us a few kinds of tea to try. Bought BOPF type and it is absolutely horrible. Total waste of money. I get better tea here in India at a better rate.

As with most other tourists, our tour guide recommended this factory because he said most other factories do not have a guide who is there to explain the process.  There was a bit of rain and the factory was about to close (I think it was after closing time). Our guide, Priya / Preeti, was nice enough to stay back and give us a tour of the factory.  Since it was after closing time, the machinery were not operational, but she gave us a full guided tour and was also able to answer most of our queries.  She was a very friendly individual and made sure that she went through the full tour, even for a group of 3 which comprised of 2 adults and 1 child. We were then lead to the tea shop, where we were given a cup of tea to sample.  Then, she showed us to all the various products that they had for sale. They had a decent selection of tea in various shapes and sizes.  The tea is of good quality, having tasted various flavors and selections from what we had bought.  However, for everyday use, the product may be a little too expensive.  As a gift or a novelty item, this would be ideal.

Stopped off here on route from Kandy to Nuwara by our driver. Looking forward to it as it is in such a beautiful location. The actual tea factory not the nicest looking place on the outside as it is just a "corrugated iron" sheet structure but it is very old. Had a quick tour of the manufacturing process from tea leaf to export sacks. Quite difficult to hear and understand the guide on occasion. Then a nice tasting complimentary tea in their adjoining cafe. and then bought some tea from the gift shop. This was MASSIVELY overpriced and when relatives opened the box on our return to the UK, there were hardly any tea leaves in the pack. Ripped off as usual!

We stopped by en route to Nuwara Eliya. Our guide was very informative, showed us the place with a lot of interest and even explained how the different types of teas are categorized,. Since then we've been speaking the language of "op and bop". Good experience if you haven't been to a tea factory. The factory is just a conventional one with nothing much different from the others.

An interesting tour of the factory to learn about the production of the different types of tea produced there. The entrance is up a fairly steep flight of steps which may challenge some. You are guided round the various stages in production and see the various machines working (little in the way of safety barriers). Because of the machinery the guide is sometimes difficult to hear. At the end you get a cup of tea and exit through the shop (of course). The area where you are served tea has some outside balconies where you can take some panoramic pictures of the tea plantation.

This tea factory is located amidst a lush green surrounding, this adds to beauty of the place. The factory itself is nothing special but the staffs were very welcoming, the restaurant had a beautiful view of the tea garden and serve some tasty snacks. You can also take a walk in the tea garden and feel refreshed with all the green surrounding you. If you want to buy some tea , they have a nice little counter for tea where you can buy some nicely packed and reasonable priced tea.
It was so useful and a worth visit to the factory...we loved the taste of tea which we preffered...thanks to eveyone who treated us very humbly..

The Glenloch tea farm is a calming and relaxing place to walk in. You get to see many locals plucking tea's. The Factory is small but worth taking the tour of how tea is made, of you haven't visited any other tea factory before. They provide some valuable information about white tea, black tea, green tea etc and is open to questions. The tea being sold is worth buying especially 'silver tips' and 'the golden flush '.  I won't recommend the green tea as it's like any other green tea and neither is the BOP/BOPF too special although they make a big deal out of it. Try the tea before you chose to buy one :)

Brought to this tea plantation factory by my tour company, and provided a perfectly spoken English-speaking guide. Interesting information about the tea making process, white tea, black tea and royal flush Ceylon tea levels of tea produce, which we have no idea about when we pick up tea packs in the supermarket. Very informative, complete with tea tasting and an opportunity to buy some as well. Recommended.

The tour was short and informative, and the friendly staff promptly provided tea of all sorts for tasting. There are plenty of places to buy your Sri Lankan tea, but when you buy it from here you know it directly benefits the factory workers.

We arrived at a quiet time. They provided a personal guide who was extremely friendly (most Sri Lankans are) and very knowledgeable. She explained everything very well, answered questions and let us wander, take photos and look around. We were certainly not rushed. They offered a cup of the locally made tea and a variety of tastings. All were extremely nice and we ended up by some for ourselves and gifts for family and friends. Some of the big name factories can be a little crowded, bug we found this one had a good balance. Not crowded, bug a god crowd in a looking.

We had such a lovely tour and learned a lot about the process of tea making. Our guide was super and we were really with how many languages he could give the tour in. You're allowed to take photos and feel/smell the tea leaves at different points in the process. The tour is free and includes and complimentary cup at the end. We got to sit out on the balcony and look out over the scenery.

We visited this tea factory in october this year. It is'nt very much. The total tour takes about 10 minutes and for me it was'nt interesting at all. The lady that guided us was not very friendly. We were only with 3 persons and I think she rather had a busload of tourists. In the factory is not very much to see.

We stopped for more of a relief stop after visiting the elephant orphanage. The driver said they maintained good toilets, he was not joking. After, we went for a tour of the factory which was excellent. We understood the gradation well. It seems I have been drinking factory floor dust all these years! After the tour and tasting, we were lead to a shop where we stocked up on quite a few ornamental packages to take home to friends. This way the manufacturer gets a fairer share of my spending dollar!

Visited here on Jan 22nd,2019. This Ceylon tea factory uses equipment from India & Japan to process tea. You can also climb the tea plantation and photo op with a tea picking basket. An employee explained us the process and lead us through the factory and you can also shop for different flavors of tea in the shop like Orange-grapefruit,black earl grey, cherry & mangoosteen etc. Sample tea drink also served here. Eatery is also attached for pastry/snacks.

We had a very interesting and informative tour of this tea factory and we really enjoyed it! I was a little skeptical before we got there, thinking that it might be dull or rigged for tourists but it was great learning about all of the different teas. The tour guide was very knowledgeable and was able to answer all of our questions, and we had the chance to try some of the teas after the tour too. Highly recommended if you're looking to visit a tea factory in Sri Lanka.

We were part of a group and had a very interesting visit around the Glenloch estate & factory. Our guide was very knowledgable and gave us an interesting & informative tour of the factory which was very detailed. We visited the plantation where we picked some leaves. A great experience. The tea tasting experience was enjoyable and there was no rush. We visited the boutique which is quite expensive but again, any purchases were our own choice. An experience worth repeating.

Visited the tea factory on our way to Nuwara Eliya from Kandy. The driver stopped there to show us the Glenloch tea factory. Were shown the process of tea factory. Then we were offered tea. And of course last we told if we would like to buy some tea. Bought Green tea And BOPF. We paid Srilankan 1000 rupees for 200 grams for both the variety. To our surprise we were not given the purchase bill. On the boxes the price was not mentioned. Even upon insisting also the sales girls refused to give the bill. Later in Colombo saw Brands like Dilsan Tea available for less than half the price. During the tour the guide told us that Dilsan Tea bought tea from Glenloch.  Felt cheated by the Glenloch tea factory. Please do not buy. Even the tea does not take any thing great after paying some crazy prices. No wonder they are not issuing bills as they are cheating tourists.

We had a great tour of the tea factory and the guide showed us and told us of each process, a tea picking competition was held after the tour with a box of tea as a prize. we sampled the tea afterwards. well worth the visit enjoyed our time here and there was a well stocked shop to browse and buy tea too.

We did not stay at the hotel but did visit the Glenloch Tea Factory en route to Kandy.  The tour was rushed and missed out half the processes.  The sole aim appeared to get us into the showroom and sell us overpriced tea and chocolates.  There must be better tea factories to visit!

Visited this factory as part of a tour group and it was very interesting. (Just would have been better if our group of 18 had been split into 2 smaller groups so it was easier to hear). After the tour got the opportunity to test the various teas before looking round the shop. There was a nice handmade chocolate counter - a few free samples might have encouraged people to buy as they looked delicious. Lovely views from the car park

Dont go by the crowd here. If the staff feels you are not going to tip them.. they will leave you all by yourself and will not even look at you. They hardly give one type of tea to taste... and in the store, the staff is only looking at western travellers. Instead.. visit smaller tea factories where you will get good personalised treatment which will make you buy some stuff. overall.. a bad experience.

We were taken around the factory, and the whole process explained to us. Our guide was knowledgeable and answered our questions, but rather unenthusiastic. He whisked us past the sign which said "Do not give tips", and hovered pointedly at the end, as we were trying the different teas. (We resisted). There is a large shop, but as soon as you show any interest the sales lady is unrelenting, so browsing is difficult.
An informative visit to a tea factory which explained the production process from picking to the tea cup. Informative but short. You do get a pleasant cup of tea however at the end.

We were recommended by our driver ( whose mother is a tea leaf picker)who we have for the week.its a working tea factory,our guide explained the process involved from tree to teacup and we found it fascinating.We both enjoy working factory experiences and the guide was fine.At the end we went into the shop and had some tea buying some rather nice chocolates to have with our teas -I don‚Äôt normally drink the stuff!
Priya gave us a lovely tour of the tea factory. Finishing off with a tea tasting at the beautiful terrace with a view over the plantations. Thanks a lot.

Very informative and interesting tour of a Tea Factory, I will never look at a teabag in the same way. Check out the machinery that is used to process the tea leaves, it is from a bygone age but as the guide said it is still the best way. After the tour of the factory enjoy a cup of tea on the shop/restaurant terrace overlooking the plantation, then browse the shop for tea to take home.

Very informative and interesting short tour of the production plant, surprising to see how simple the process is. Finishing with a lovely cup of their tea (of course) and surprisingly for Sri Lanka, free! Was amazing to see bus loads of Chinese tourists packing huge boxes of tea to take home!
A cup of tea will never be the same, now that I have understood and seen the complex process involved!

The factory is the same as others, but the tea lobby is very nice. Good to look and have a tea. I thing, their tea was the most expensive of all, where I been, but try the lobby, the shopping is not the must.
Very informative visit ladies who show you around are lovely.. free tea tasting.. free entry.. tea shop is lovely. & a go at tea picking with the tea ladies

Our driver took us there for lunch with us having no idea that we will get to visit a tea factory as well. A good surprise. In short food was good. We were served with complimentary cups of tea as well which tasted really refreshing. Tour of tea factory was not too long but the guide gave good insights on how different kind of teas are prepared. Well recommended.

Enjoyed seeing and hearing how the tea manufacturing worked, all explained by a lovely young lady. Saw the different types of tea, then into the cafe for a cuppa. Not very nice tea at all which was a shame as we would have purchased for gifts etc. I feel they need to put more thought into this aspect of the tour if they wish visitors to purchase tea. Quite slap dash at the end, perhaps if they introduced a tea tasting experience, similar to a winery it may be more enjoyable.

Since we arrived all employees were very nice and polite. The rooms were very big and bed very comfortable, also with a nice view on tea hills. In the morning after breakfast we visited the tea factory and tea plantation. Ms. Shiva guided us trough it with a perfect and detailed explanation and after she showed us how to take and select the right leaves in order to have the perfect tea. After a tea tasting we could buy some of their delicious teas. Thank you very much for this experience! A special thanks to Ms. Shiva and all the hotel employees.

Interesting free tour of an old tea factory with some of the original equipment still there, all the workers were toiling at their various jobs from sorting, sifting, drying the tea to packaging it for auction.  Our guide was a bit perfunctory and difficult to understand but most of the processes were obvious.  One thing to note, all the workers were barefoot. At the end of the tour you are offered a cup of tea, either black, green or white (white is the most flavoursome) and then can purchase from a variety of boxed tea, a bit overpriced as most tourist items are in Sri Lanka. When we were there there were several coaches and people in the cafeteria, so be aware it is a real tourist stop, but interesting if you want to learn how tea is processed.

Interesting old style tea processing factory and equipment.  Some old equipment is preserved for historical interest.  Our free tour guide was mechanical and perfunctory but as there were only two of us, I think she was keen to get to the next (hopefully larger) group of tourists.  Free cup of tea in the tea shop was OK but limited choice to select from.  The limited selection of tea packs on sale were ridiculously priced. If you want to buy tea in Sri Lanka I recommend you visit the markets where the locals buy.  We got some lovely silver tip tea in a small spice shop in Galle at very reasonable price.

On our trip towards Nuwara Eliya we stopped off for a visit at the Glenloch Tea Factory. The Guide shows you upstairs in the tea sorting room and explains the process involved in tea production. The machinery is very old but obviously still does the job. Workers seemed used to having tourists watch them work. You can take photos. Even thou there is a clear sign not to tip the Guide you are put in a position to discreetly pass him something. I did not see the Tip Box. After the tour a very nice hot cuppa is provided. No idea what type we were given as we were left in peace to enjoy it. No pressure made to purchase any tea as the shop was busy with a bus of tourists. We did not have the opportunity to walk amongst the tea bushes but our driver very kindly offered a stop further down the road.

Stoped there on our way to Nuwara Eliya. Visit was rushed. The lady dropped us for a Tamil group which had just arrived half way through. Tea tasting was weak tea which didn‚Äôt make us want to buy much...

The tour conducted here was very comprehensive and was absolutely free. The guides answer questions clearly and there is even an opportunity to taste the tea for free! Tea sold here is decently priced.

Tour and tea tasting are free. However, the tea tasting is a disappointment. If you want to buy tea, this is the place to be ripped off. A total no go.. it's a surprise how they are still on business. If your tour is taking you there, avoid shopping!

We were on the road from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya and took an hour to stop at the Glenloch Tea Factory. We were invited to pick tea leaves in the fields and so began our first lessons in the art of tea making. So many things to learn but our guide Ganga, made our tour really enjoyable. We then entered the main processing part of the tour, learning how the tea leaves are dried, ground, filtered and crushed before being roasted. The kids and adults had a great experience, finished off by tea tasting. The atmosphere was relaxed and there was no pressure to purchase along the way...however by the time we had finished everyone wanted to buy some tea. Thanks again to Ganga for making the tour so much fun.
Very interesting... A lot of work goes into producing that perfect "cup" of tea! They have a well stocked shop where various blends of loose tea can be purchased!

This holiday was our first visit to Sri Lanka and we really wanted to do a tea factory/tea picking visit. This one was recommended and organised by the local travel agent (ground agent for Kuoni). I imagine this is not dissimilar to other tea factory offerings and as far as I was concerned ticked all the relevant boxes. What surprised me most was that we were touring  a working, commercial operation and allowed to get up close and handle the (largely ancient) equipment and the tea in its different process stages. I was expecting something slightly more sanitised behind Perspex screens with UK-style endless warnings about health and safety etc but blessedly there was none of that. Our friendly guide gave us a brisk tour of the different stages but never hurried us when we wanted to look closer, take photos and generally dilly-dally taking the place in. Information she gave was hugely informative and I learnt a lot about the process. After the machinery we had a tea tasting of 4 of the teas (slightly disappointingly we were just left alone to sample while our guide disappeared - some tasting pointers or things to look out for would have added to the experience) then guided through the retail operation to part with money. We didn't mind and there is no obligation to buy anything and the prices were probably not unreasonable. Finally we had a brief tea-picking experience. Basket-strung-from-the-head photo opportunity rather than a picking experience but was good to do if only to appreciate how hard the real tea pickers work for their low wages. Doing this, my wife managed to pick up a leech too which wasn't part of the formal picking experience but served to again emphasise just one of the hazards of the job for real! (Could have been worse - could have been a venomous snake bite!). A must do if you love tea and this was a good tour in a real working factory with an enthusiastic guide.

Stopped here and had a tour of the factory. Quite interesting particularily some of the victorian machinery still being used but the tour is brief. Then it is into the cafe and shop where you can try a varirty of teas and purchase different teas and souvenirs. Typical tourist type place.

The Tea factory is located in a natural scenic backdrop.A cup of hot and tasty Ceylon tea is served to us.I had a factory tour.Very good explanation about the production of tea was given by one the Glenloch staff. Excellent place to tour.

We visited as part of a Tour group en route from Kandy to the Hill Country. We did the Factory tour with full process explanations from an English speaking employee. Then a tasting experience and on to the shop, with innumerable tea offerings. Good stop off.

Fairly attractive premises externally and a nice balcony area to sit and sample the various teas produced on the estate while listening to a commentary on their origins and production. Then it as off to the factory where the guide took us through the various stages from picking, drying, fermenting, etc. Interesting talk but difficult to hear with the noise of the machinery. No noise reduction earmuffs being worn or evident anywhere. From there we progressed to the shop where the finished product in all it's varieties awaited us in assorted packets, containers, tins, presentation boxes, etc. I enjoyed the tastings when we arrived but considered the priced product way higher than I expected and did not make a purchase despite the best endeavors and entreaties of the fashionable sales ladies.  Interesting visit and we left with a greater appreciation of the conditions that are experienced by the workforce before our favourite brands reach the shelves.

I really enjoyed the visit to this tea factory. It was really interesting to see the process from beginning to end. This is still a thriving and active tea factory. Very informative and great to see the various stages of production. Enjoyed the smells too. Good tasting experience at the end and of course, we bought some!

We visited while on a bike tour. They factory has a nice balcony where you can sample tea (we had four kinds: English Breakfast, Green, White, and Special). They were all quite good, and were a healthy sample size. The balcony overlooked a valley, and was quite a pleasant view. However, there is some major construction happening right below the balcony which was a bit noisy, but hopefully it will be terminated soon. The tour guides wanted to know if we wanted to eat, but all they had was mostly things we don't eat (breads, pasta, cake and cookies, etc), and it was on the pricey side, so we declined. However, the other guests seemed to like their food, so it might be a good place to eat. We were then taken on a factory and plantation tour, both which were very interesting since to that point I really didn't know how tea was made, and the difference between black, green, white, and a new tea that I had never heard of 'silver tip'. Apparently it is mainly about the different age of the leafs, and then their is very little difference aside from the fact that black tea is fermented and then dried, whereas the others are steamed. We then bought some tea in the gift shop, which was very reasonably priced, and then I went to have one more delicious green tea before we started to ride again. To my great surprise, they gave me the extra tea again for free since I had bought some tea in the gift shop. The gift shop had all sorts of teas, in all types of formats. They had all the teas mentioned in the samples above, and they had mixes with herbal ingredients. They also had most in loose and bad format. Lastly, they had packages in different sizes and containers. I wanted pure green tea, and I was offered a 200 gram loose tea in a simple box for 1100 rupees, or 100 gram in a display tin for 1000 rupees. Our tour guide was very nice, and was informed. Overall, if you like tea, or are just looking for a nice view, consider stopping here, or at one of the many tea plantations along the way.

Review Title: A visit to the Glenloch Tea estate
Review Text: Tea plants thrive in a specific combination of ideal climate, diverse geography, rich soil, and consistent rainfall. Sri Lanka‚Äôs central highlands offer these perfect conditions: high altitudes provide cool temperatures, high humidity, and plentiful, well-distributed rain to hydrate the vegetation. It is this "Goldilocks zone" that allows the slow growth necessary for complex flavors to develop in high-quality tea leaves. A visit to the Glenloch Tea estate immerses you in this environment, featuring a tour of the lush tea fields, the intricate leaf processing factory, and a tasting session. Afterward, guests can explore a well-stocked, if relatively expensive, gift shop to purchase their favorite blends.

When you do the must-visit tea factory tour I guess it depends a lot on the guide. Our guide was pleasant and knowledgeable and answered our questions competently and politely.This factory has some quite old machinery which is fascinating in its own right.You can also visit the plantation itself but we seemed to be left alone to do that if we wished. You are given five varieties of tea to taste, which was served with a smile and was nicely hot. Then of course the shop - and what seemed expensive packets of tea. But we did follow the notice saying no tips - which is probably the only one you will see in Sri Lanka!

We had earlier on visited a tea museum in a former tea factory so it was very interesting to visit an active tea factory to see the different processes and all the different kinds of tea made from the same plant. We had a free cup of tea and also had the chance to taste and compare green tea, white tea and brown tea. (We can recommend the brownie cake in the cafe, it didn‚Äôt look as fancy as the other cakes in the display but it had a good taste)

Having spent 4 days in the beautiful Ella and Nuwara Eliya areas we were disappointed by this factory tour. Short and non motivational followed by pressure to buy what we discovered  later was ‚Äúexpensive‚Äù tea.

Got an informative tour of the factory and the teas they produce by a friendly young woman, saw some of the tea-picking action, and were served 3 types of teas to try. The tea shop seemed a little expensive but was worth it considering the effort they put into the tour.

We found the tour of the very interesting and the experience  of picking the tea. I would agree with other travellers that it seemed very rushed to the point of just getting you in and out. We were offered a visit to the shop after having cups of the different types of tea,this we declined as I suspected it would be over priced I am sure that there are better ones in the area. So if you have a choice try somewhere else that might take more time with you

We had a fabulous tour at this working tea factory. Our guide was extremely knowledgeable and it was fascinating to see how tea is processed and hear how the process has evolved over time. The tea tasting at the end of the tour was a nice way to end, and they allowed us to try the more expensive teas at no cost. We also ate lunch here which was tasty and well priced. We didn't feel any pressure to purchase in the shop, although we did, however they listened to what we wanted and our budget and showed us only that. Highly recommend a visit.

Glenloch is 2 or 3 hours drive from Kandy but it is well worth the journey if, like me, you have never seen a tea plantation before.  En route you pass through interesting countryside including tea growing areas as you get closer, and there are great views as you get higher.  The factory tour and the tasting are really interesting and I am very glad I went.  One point: tea pickers are very poor indeed so they are very persistent if given a chance to beg: you should take quite a few small banknotes with which to thank them if you photograph them.

Visit on recommendation of my guide. Tour of the factory, well explained, nothing in a hurry, though I went solo. Bought some Gold Tea, White Tea, Golden Pekoe and Silver Tips after the tasting. Decent lunch with stunning views over the mountain and the lake. Maybe there are better tea factories, but I was quite happy to have visited Glenloch.
Beautiful tea factory and friendly guides that walk you through tea making process. Complimentary cup of tea. Can go and walk up in tea fields if desire.

The tour was interesting in what it was, though we had a very disinterested, dry tour guide not only that a couple of cheeky factory workers tricked us into paying for a photo of the station they where working in (we hadn't seen the no tipping factory workers sign at that stage).
Visit is worth the stop in house guide has her talk down to a tea gift shop is well stocked.Take time to walk the tea garden the views around are amazing

Stopped here on the way to Nuwara Eliya - in the middle of fantastic countryside - and was a fascinating insight into how tea is made. Something we take for granted. The factory and machinery is quite old and it felt like a real working place which we were fortunate enough to see - the whole process was very well explained too. The tour was free and the guide was very nice and informative and there was none of the 'hard sell' that you get at some of these places. Complimentary tea at the end and some nice tea products in the shop. We really enjoyed our visit and it was one of the highlights of our holiday.

We spent a pleasant hour here having the factory tour & then a cup of tea & fish croquettes in the cafe. I wouldn't go out of my way to visit this place, but it was free (apart from the croquet & tips) & did break up a long & winding trip from Kandy to Ella

A tea factory and visitor centre situated in a stunning location with panoramic views of the surrounding areas and tea plantations An ideal stop off point for a snack or meal Glen Loch has a great restaurant with an outside terrace to view the scenery. It does host coach parties so can be very busy if several arrive at the same time It is possible to have a free tea tasting. Samples of the various teas (Gold, Silver, Green and Breakfast) are served in china cups. Although I am not a tea drinker I enjoyed the experience very much Of course there is a shop where you can buy the tea and many other gifts

Complete waste of time to visit this place. They provide a guided tour with a very very disinterested guide and then plonk some cups of teas in front after the ‚Äútour‚Äù (which in itself is a non-event) is out of the day. There is the ubiquitous shop which sells teas at a price far higher than what we usually pay in supermarkets in our home country. It‚Äôs free but that does not mean you waste precious time here. In a nutshell it‚Äôs a favorite of tour guides and drivers which is usually a good sign of a ‚Äútourist trap‚Äù or place to avoid.

The tour of the tea factory was very interesting with incredible smells. Refreshingly, we weren‚Äôt pestered or rushed into the shop at the end as one usually is at the end of such tours. Even so, the shop was very busy as the prices are good and the quality of the tea is high. They also offer free tastings of the different teas they make.

The second of the 2 tea factory tours we went on. The other was at Pedro, and we feel this is the better one. A comparison of the 2 below Glenloch : It operates for most of the day, and we got full access to the factory floor. And as close as we would like to the machinery. In total the tour was 45 mins around the factory, and we could take as many photos as we wanted. Has a nice shop area at the end, where you can purchase, and also sample for free, their offerings Pedro : stops working at 10am, as they told us they do most processing at night. We came just after that, and it was being washed down. No point coming on a factory tour if it's not working. Also they really didn't want you taking photos, and asked you to put the camera away.
