Got just 1 sample of tea  and it is their budget offering. Winner : by far it is Glenloch

A must go place!  We were greeted with traditional Namesty, and lots of smiling faces. A lady named Kamaleshawari took us around and guided us thru the factory. It is quite a neat place. They also have a very nice tea lounge and shopping places. The tea made there is not of very high quality maybe. The blend wasn't of our liking! We stayed in a place just above the factory. The Glenloch villa, very nice place! I am really thankful to the tea factory Incharge for making it possible for my package to reach Colombo airport before we left Srilanka. Really nice people!!

On the way to Nuwareliya from Kandy, this factory is located near pussawella. Nice place situated amidst the tea estates. Lot of tamil women working in this tea factory. A person named mrs.sasikala explained us about various types of tea and tea leaves processing. They also offered us a cup of aromatic sri lankan tea free of cost. It tastes excellent. Nice place to relax and sip a good tea.

As tea lovers we were looking forward to a few hours at Glenloch and we weren‚Äôt disappointed. Our guide was very knowledgable and explained the whole process of the tea manufacturing from start to finish. We were given a tour throughput the factory, took photo‚Äôs and asked questions. It was fascinating to see and so incredible what goes into it all. We got a chance to puck some tea leaves which was great fun! Afterwards we got to try some of the different varieties and purchase some from their well stocked shop. Brilliant tour and highly recommend.

We went when they were about to shut, but even then they took us around and explained to us in detail, what is the process of tea making.Very knowledgeable got to taste the various teas. overall very interesting.

Our family were on a tour and we stopped off here. It was extremely fascinating and the kids enjoyed it thoroughly. Even the kids tried the tea. (Only one enjoyed!!!). We had cake with our tea and even that was cheap! I highly recommend this location!

We must have had a bad tour guide, because everyone else seems to have had a good experience here. Our tour guide spent less than 10 minutes with us. She rushed us through the processing rooms, didn't speak loud enough to hear her over the machinery and only seemed interested in getting us into the gift shop -- and it wasn't even a busy day! This would have been an ideal location for a full tour. We would have loved to walk through the fields to see the workers picking the tea, and to take the time to understand how the tea is processed. But we learned very little with our whirlwind tour. It was nice to have a complimentary cup of tea at the end of the tour, however. We had such wonderful experiences all over Sri Lanka. The locals could not be more accommodating and friendly. This was the only sour note in our entire visit to this lovely, welcoming country. Perhaps the tour guide was just having a bad day...

As a chauffeur guide it is us who recommend the guest/ tourist about a hotel or restuarant for lunch. Yesterday I had to take my guests to Glenloch for lunch and i am seriously disappointed the way they treated us. Is it fair to charge for guides meal as we take the guest for the restuarant ? The staff is so rude saying that the guest had only one portion meal therefore i had to pay for guide meal. This will be the first and last time we will take a guest for your restuarant. Hereafter will not recommend glenloch for anyone. For your kind information this message will be forwarded to all tourist guide groups and relavant tourism companies as well. Glen lodge do not forget that you gain your business mostly through our (guides)  recommendations.

An attractive young woman took us and an Italian couple round the factory. She had clearly repeated the same information many times over and seemed somewhat stopped in her tracks when we showed interest and asked questions. She appeared eager to get us through to the end and give us a cup of tea, before escorting us through to the shop, where we were clearly expected to buy some tea. In our opinion the prices were extortionate and we left without purchasing. The young lady appeared very disappointed. Not clear if she has to rely on the sales that are made. Our driver who chose to take us here rather than a factory that I asked to go to, was also very clearly upset that we didn't buy and tried (in vain) to persuade us to go back in and buy some!
Subhashini, Explained very well stage by stage which was exemplary.  We recommend this place honestly. Thanks, Vettri

This tea factory makes a great pit-stop when travelling between Kandy and Ella. We arrived just as a coach tour was leaving and although crowded we had an English speaking guide to ourselves. The tour took us through the full sequence of preparing tea and we learnt about the difference between the varieties ( Strong, Pekoe, Green  etc.)  The restrooms were clean. the tour ended with a tasting of several varieties of teas, after which we bought some for ourselves and as gifts for friends. The only downside was that  Livingston Harvest Green Tea with Raspberry and Strawberry we brought home  expecting a tasty fruit tea turned out to be a coarse green tea with no additives that is undrinkable. It tasted and looked like a cabbage leaf tea...not at all what is to be expected of any sri lankan tea.

This is a typical stop arrange by the taxi drivers and tour operators to put tourist in commercially tourist shops. They sell it as a "tea factory tour" but is basically a show around the factory to end in the factory souvenir shop to be force either to tip the tour guide or to buy a very expensive selection of tea's. This is very common in this part of the world. You would see this kind of stops in Thailand, Indonesia and even in India. The Spice Garden is something very similar and its around the corner. You might buy something that you like but at a very expensive price (for Sri Lanka). But don't allow to be push around with this methodology. If you don't wanna stop or buy, nobody can force you.

Glenloch seemed smaller than other tea factories we had seen around, but we really enjoyed it. We had a tour with another couple (who were French - our guide lady said 'I will explain slowly because they are French' lol!) to see how the tea was produced. The machines were fascinating and the whole area smelt so fragrant. After the short tour, you are given a cup of tea which was really nice (and I don't like tea... yeah, I said it!) apart from the massive spider I could be hanging from the rafters. Husband bought a couple of boxes of tea. All in all a nice little stop!

it's smaller than Mackwood Factory but still nice place to visit. the tour was nice and guide is a nice guy after that we have been given some cups of tea and it was awesome so I went to the store and bought some packs and that's really recommended. things I didn't like are the tea lounge were you get your complementary tea was awful and need to get finished and have a nice interior and the exterior .. same goes to the store . still they have the best tea ever (royal tea).

We stopped here on our travels,  we were met by a friendly lady who showed us around explaining all the processes in tea making. We even had a go at picking the tea leaves with traditional baskets. Great experience well worth a visit.

This is the first tea factory o e gets to see while heading to Nuwara Eliya. The factory has guides to take you on an informative walk around the tea factory. It is pretty informative for children as well as adults. Finally one gets to enjoy tea tasting and you can also buy the tea from there. It makes a good gift for people back home.
Lovely tour guide Gung and smashing teas to taste afterwards. And a very beautiful setting. Definitely worth stopping by.

Lovely Tea Factory.  It was great to see the original 150 year old factory, with all the original machinery.  Everyone was really nice and we had a tea tasting at the end.  Huge shop with lots of Tea's to take home.

Quite informative tour, demonstrating how tea is produced.  It was quite short and curt and lacked real detail.  The opportunity to try tea picking was good.  Tasting was just of one brew - which was disappointing.  The shop had a decent range of products available
Short visit, quick tour from informative guide, interesting. Quick tasting and visit to the shop. Toilets clean. Enough said.

We arrived at Glenloch around 8.15 am, hungry and tired after almost 2 hrs ride from Kandy - so we wanted some breakfast, and some tea. Since the service started only at 8.30 am, the staff asked us to order our food and take a look at the accompanying shop. We ended up buying all kinds of tea brands from them. :) Breakfast was very heavy. We had ordered club sandwich, cheese and tomato sandwich, cheese and tomato omelette, milk tea and green tea. Green tea was on the house. And the milk tea was out of this world - so much so that we had to ask the brand, and each one of us bought at least one packet on Glenloch BOPF. You must try (and buy) this. The sandwich was too much for us, so we doggy-bagged them. But it was tasty. The service staff were very cordial. The place itself is lovely, a bit up the hill, with a sit-out that overlooks the hill. There was enough place to seat at least around 150 people at one time. After breakfast, we went for a visit inside the tea factory, and the young lady guided us and gave a brief history of tea making in a sing song voice. That itself is an unique experience. This is a short tour, and you must take it to understand the different nuances of tea production. Worth the time spent.

My husband and I visited the tea factory as part of a 4 day tour we had booked through Hayes and Jarvis called "Cultural Kandy and Tea." The tour of the factory was detailed and the guide was very informative. He told us to pose near the tea for photos etc and took some photos for us. We viewed the whole tea making process, which was fascinating. However, at the end of the tour we were taken up to a terrace and provided with a cup of tea (which tasted fantastic by the way) and the guide stood over us, clearly waiting for a tip. My husband explained to him that our other guide (who was driving us around for the whole trip) had not yet taken us to a cash machine and so we had no money to give for a tip. We apologised profusely, however the man just stayed there stood over us, which made us feel very uncomfortable. After a while he gave up, a lady came over and took our cups away quite rudely. I was feeling quite mortified by this time and thought I would at least buy something from the gift shop with my bank card so that we would at least spend some money there. Again, the staff in the shop were abrupt, the lady who served me practically threw my bank card at me. We couldn't leave there quickly enough. I think it should be made much more clear that tips are expected here; we always tip generously, however I think sometimes it helps to remember that we had already paid several thousands of pounds for our holiday, which included the tour. It also wasn't our fault that our driver hadn't taken us to an ATM machine! (I had actually tried to take money out at the airport but he advised against it). I would recommend the trip, however please be advised that you will not be treated very nicely if you don't tip the guide.

the people get paid ¬£4 a day to pick the tea and they still smile and want you to smile back ! you a free cup of tea that is produced where you have just seen we brought some home and its amazing ! better than your tesco,asda sainsbury's

Most tea factories have become just for tourists and are there for show, however Glenloch was different. This factory was a lot less busy, so the guide we had didn‚Äôt need to rush us through. We was able to see all the staff at work and also were able to take pictures (most of the factories don‚Äôt allow this.) It was fascinating to see the process of tea making! At the end we was able to taste 5 different types of tea with gorgeous views of the tea fields. What‚Äôs best is all of this is free! There‚Äôs a huge selection of teas to buy afterwards, some that come in beautiful wodden boxes, which make great gifts! Would recommend this trip to any tea lover!

What a amazing place.  We just drink tea and say what a taste.  But there are lots and lots of affords behind it.  Very nice process , high quality tea packed in front of you.  Make sure that you bye one.  And you can enjoy the hills of tea plantation. It's very cold. Please take warm clothes.  You can bye organic vegetables too.
Best place to hear about the tea manufacture . The staff is so nice and you feel that they do their job with a big pleasure

Recommend this experience, Your guide takes you through the factory, explains the process. You have a tasting, and then venture into the plantation, where you can try your hand at plucking ! Not at all crowded, a great experience.

Our driver recommended the place. We first had a short tour around the factory then we went to the plantation, where we tried to pick the tea leaves on our own. Afterwards we had a brief tea tasting and then we could shop in the local store. We liked the tea with guava and sour sop, so the store has prepared for us a few extra cans.

Interesting and informative stop on any trip between Kandy and Nuwara Eliya. A guide takes you round the factory explaining the process and the function of each of the machines (absolutely necessary - there's a withering area, a rolling process, Fermentation/Oxidisation process, drying machine, grading room, etc.) and you end up in a tea-tasting caf√®, on a balcony which gives you a panoramic view of the Mataweli River valley. Finally, there's a shop.

This a nice relaxing tour around the tea factory. It's interesting to see how it gets made, it's a laborious task and the machines are still quite rudimentary. Enjoy some tea and cake in the restaurant afterwards, there are nice views. The tour is free with a tip box system in use at the end of the tour

The visit is very informative, despite the coldness of our hostess A visit to the store is essential, but there, the staff is really anti-commercial. You are there to buy and not to ask questions!! The saleswoman gives us a dented box and never wanted to change it, claiming that there were no more
Nice walk on the tea blending process and visit to the tea factory. Its an educational tour but they expect you to buy tea at the end which is quite expensive. Some teas were really good.

Nice visit at Glenloch tea factory. We had a english speaking guide who showed us the tea factory. She told us all about the process. We could ask questions and she gave us good answers. Afterwards we got to taste black, white, green tea. Nice store where you could buy tea. Good experience!

Visiting a tea factory is a must when visiting SriLanka.   The amazing fresh tea smell permeates the air, and the landscape of Nuwara Eliya is beautiful.   Glenloch is no exception. Our guide to the tea factory spouted many dodgy facts about tea.  For example, she seemed to think black tea was high in vitamin C and had more vitamin C than green tea.   She did not know what fermentation or oxidation were.  When I asked questions to clarify her knowledge, she hit back by asking my travel partner whether I could understand English. Ouch!  She then treated me like a retard who couldn't understand what she was saying, which was totally fine with me, because I knew she didn't know even the basics of the tea making process.   I have attached a picture of the dodgy guide.   Surely it takes only 10minutes of reading Wikipedia to pass some basic facts on and she couldn't even do that. I've attached a pic of the guide. We didn't get a tour of the plantation outside.  We were told we could wander down the path/road to take a better look outside.  We weren't allowed to walk on the plantation slopes as a safety precaution. Once inside, we tasted just one type of tea. It was OK.   The shop was a bit overpriced.  I bought BOP tea in the cheapest packaging, it was 1000rupees. No discounts, no haggling.   Our driver was pretty happy because he got some free tea from the ladies there once we had made our purchases.  I think drivers who bring visitors to Glenloch obviously get perks which depend on how much their visitors spend -  that's enough incentive for them to choose this tea factory over others.  The tea itself tastes great.   Heaps better than the Dilmah you get in Australia. In this factory, the same tea gets packaged as different brands.  The price point is just determined by how fancy the brand is, which is mainly comes down to how beautiful the packaging is.   So you might as well buy the no frills packaging.

We visited this factory as it was selected by our driver/guide. Mondays a bad, as no tea picking takes places on Sunday, so half of the tour was looking at machines, standing still, as no activity took place. The guide was friendly and knowledgeable, and the free tea tasting was very nice. there are nice views from the tea house.

This plantation and factory is worth visiting. It is not overly commercial and still has much of the original machinery.  As an avid tea drinker I learnt a lot, especially about tea dust. The ladies who looked after us were warm, friendly and a little wicked, in a nice way. A tip: there is no picking on Sunday thus the machinery does not operate on Monday. That is when the factory is cleaned.

I had no idea how the different kinds of tea were processed before my visit here; and it was very interesting to see a real factory at work close up with an informative guide. Free cups of the finished product were available to taste and although it was, as usual, exit via the gift shop, it was nice that no-one put any pressure on us to buy anything

Not being a tea drinker I honestly didn't think that I would get anything from the tour experience at the tea factory but was i so wrong I had a great time learning about different teas and how the leaves are picked by hand and dried and then ground the lady that showed us around was awesome ( sorry I forgot your name but see pictures) . I didn't like the tea tasting but in all honesty I drink coffee as my preference however others in my party love it.

What a fantastic place this is.  So full of history and demonstration of the hard working people who patiently pick the tea leaves that we all enjoy around the world.  We did a short tour that is free but there is a box to place tips for the staff.  They share these which is a good and fair system.  Then you are able to do tea tasting and select tea for purchase. I got carried away shopping again but it is so fresh how can you revisit. I would buy more of the exotic white and silver tea next time.

Glenloch Tea was established 150 years ago and that in its self is quite remarkable to still be processing tea for export around the world. The tour was interesting to watch the process from start to finish and enjoy several tasting cups of tea at the end. The staff were friendly and we felt no pressure to make a purchase....but we did however and my family now wish me to track down were I can purchase it in Australia!

It is very quite place where you can get information about tea fabrication and its history. Also you can have a lucnh or dinner in the reataurant. Prices is not high and quality of foods is very good. I you are not the maniac of tea don't buy tea in this place. Because it is expencive, but not the best. Just enjoy history, nature and meal :)

Unplanned visit. we were short on time for going towards nuwara eliya from kandy. I dont drink tea in fact never tasted. Our driver recommended so decided to take a small stop. Interesting and informative tour and follow up with a free cup of tea (if you like to). We ended up buying lot of tea for family and friends :)

You get to see the journey of the famed Ceylon tea from the field to your cup. The guide shows you all the processes involved and also the various types of tea that is made. At the end of the tour you get to taste each variety of tea before making a purchase( optional)

This is such a beautiful tea plantation. We were guided round the factory and explained the process by Divya. Divya then took us to taste the tea and pick tea in the plantations ourselves. Excellent service, brilliant experience and delicious tea.

Of all the tea estates to visit do not choose this one. Our driver insisted we come here because it is one of the estates that is 100% Sri Lankan owned. Whilst I wanted to support local business the way we were treated here was disappointing. The lady provided a very rushed tour, she had no expression on her face and often yawned. When we asked any questions she was reluctant to answer. Of course at the end she wanted her tip and when we were browsing the shop she suddenly became interested in helping us (perhaps she gets a commission). We were so excited to visit this beautiful part of Sri Lanka but being treated like we were just $$ took the pleasure out of our experience. I have heard other estates provide more customer service training to their staff and might be better to visit. I hope the owners of the Glenloch estate read this and review their service levels.

The tour takes <15 mins where they will explain about the process of making the tea. Afterwhich, they will let you sample some tea. There's a shop onsite. Its up to individuals whether they wish to buy.

We really enjoyed our tour of this tea factory and learning how tea is made. We had no idea it is such a long process. You are given some tea to sample in the cafe at the end and then inevitably we bought a fair amount to bring home. The only irritant was the lady in the shop who followed us round as we were browsing the teas almost hassling us to buy!

Each group gets it's own free guide, however due to the large number of visitors, they rush the tour so that they can move onto the next group. Although the factory tour was a mere 5 minutes, it was quite interesting to see the tea making process (4 teas from a single plant). Thereafter they let you taste a cup of tea (no milk). But at this point, the guide disappears, so it's best to ask questions before they go. Then, the salesmen take over and try to sell you the overpriced tea. In conclusion, we drove up from Kandy to visit the tea plantations, and had we known it would have just been a 5 minute experience, we wouldn't have wasted a night at Nuwara Eliya.

Our driver took us here on the way to the Heritance Tea Factory hotel.  It was a really interesting visit.  We never realised just how many processes went into making tea.  We really do take it for granted with our tea bags back home!!!  A gentleman took us round who was the amanger, showing us the full process, we could take pictures and the staff were smiling whilst working away non stop.  After the factory tour he took us to see the tea plantation next to the factory so we could see and touch the tea bushes.  Once the tour was finished, he took us to the shop where we had a complimentary cup of tea which was delicious.  My husband gave him what we thought was a reasonable tip, considering there is a tip box in the shop, we shouldn't be expected to give twice.  He was the manager, was certainly on a better wage than the tea factory workers.  He mumbled something under his breath about the tip not being big enough.  We just politely smiled and walked away!!! We bought a box of various fruit teas for us to enjoy at home.  Worth a visit but make sure you don't have the greedy manager show you round!!!!

This is a chance to see how the tea as picked starts the process into your cup. The actual tea factory looks like every other one in the area, apparently using a design perfected in the 19th century, with machinery invariably from the UK.  It is however interesting to see the process in action, starting with a sort of fermentation where a lot of the water content is removed naturally, through a grinding into small segments and then a final drying.  The there's a lot more to it, particularly the blending, testing, tasting and packaging, but those are the initial steps. All the time specialised machinery is doing the real work. After an informative tour showing the process you are invited to a tasting session where you can try and distinguish between the various products.  Finally, there is the opportunity to buy some genuine Ceylon tea.  I have to say that I did not find the selling to be very pushy. For a visit of just over an hour I found this to be very interesting.
Interesting tour on the tea making process in an old factory. Enjoyed the tea tasting after the tour and bought tea to take home from the shop.

I didn't know this place. The driver took me there and I've loved the place. The explanation  is very clear and illuminance. Leads you step by step into the creation of tea; white,green,black,strong and delicate. At the end they serve you a taste of all the  qualities and of course the tour ends in their shop where you can buy every kind of tea. After that it is mendetory to step into the tea plants to take some picture with their basket on the shoulders.

We stopped here to visit the tea factory and the plantation. The tea pickers demonstrated their skills and the factory workers the process of producing tea. This was followed by a tea tasting session of various strengths and types before visiting the onsite shop.

This tea factory/plantation was fantastic. I have attached a picture of our guide. Believed to be in her late 20's, she was very sweet, professional and knowledgable! Seeing the whole process of how tea is made was really interesting and I was surprised to learn that all different types of tea come from the same plant just a different leaf! I always assumed it was a different tea plant all together. We got to taste the tea afterwards and after tasting how fresh and how creamy the taste was, of course we had to buy some! I will be absolutely gutted when I run out of the tea! It tastes amazing. Our tea back home is nothing in comparison to here. I definitely believe this is the place to visit if you want to see a tea plantation/factory. I was told by my driver that this is the only tea factory still owned by Sri Lanka. This was sad to learn. Please visit this place rather than the places owned by large corporations! You'll never taste tea better than you do here. Also, if the owner of this factory is reading this review, the lady I have uploaded a photo of deserves a promotion, she was superb.

We had visited similar places in India and China but still enjoyed our tour of Glenloch.  We had a lovely guide who explained the whole process and at the end enjoyed a tasting of a couple of the teas. Finally, we were allowed to do a bit of tea picking, touristy yes but still good fun.

A must stop on the way to Ella. The tour is completely free, with samples of tea at the end. We had the amazing Divya give us the tour. Her English was impeccable and she was so knowledgeable, having worked there for 10 years! Their tea is so delicious, we couldn't resist buying some in the lovely shop at the end.
The old English sorting machines are still doing their job. The team also added a new machine, which can be seen. The tea tastes wonderful.

My husband and I were enroute from Kandy to Nanuoya to catch the midday train to Ella. Our driver recommended we leave very early so we could stop in Nuwara Eliya to visit Glenloch as it is Sri Lankas tea capital apparently. Tour was just the two of us and the lady spoke excellent English and zipped us around the factory in about 10-15min which was fine for us and free (just tip as you please). Tried a couple of teas and bought some as well (no pressure to buy which was nice).

We called in to this tea factory and were treated to a tour of the factory which was very informative Following the tour we had a free cup of tea which unlike se of the bought ones in the supermarket has no chemicals and is so nice u don't need milk or sugar Entrance is free also
Never buy anything from the tea factory they will cheat you. We purchased worth Rs. 13000/- (Sri Lankan) tea from outlet of factory all most all the containers are having tea dust...

As a tea lever I enjoyed my one on my one tour here. The tour started with a visit inside the factory. From here we went outside into the tea plantation where I had a small look into the life of a picker. My last stop was a visit to the cafe where I was treated to a tasting of 4 different teas. Make sure you treat your self to a cholesterol or other treat too! I finished my tour off with a visit to the shop to purchase some tea to take home with me to Australia. The tour itself was free, I just tipped my lovely guide!

Tour delivered in a speedy and robotic fashion - was difficult to understand and then man marked in the shop and felt pressured to purchase something, weren‚Äôt able to browse at own pace. Tea tasting was good though.

Recommended by our driver and listed in our copy of Lonely Planet, we had a very good brief stop here. Lunch was simple but very tasty, the tour was short but very interesting. In fact, they were bagging up tea during the tour which meant we got to see the factory working. Afterwards we had a complimentary cup of tea - which was lovely. Shop is not over-priced for being direct from the source. A worthwhile tea factory tour.

Like many others we stopped at Glenloch on our way from Kandy to Nuwara Eliya.   Because of the number of visitors we weren't able to find a guide who had been recommended.  And so the young woman who was available began to explain the tea making process.  Within moments it became clear that she would rather be elsewhere.  We began to feel that we were imposing as she recited her memorized script.  She  seemed  to discourage questions.   The explanation that she provide was adequate albeit quite basic.  After our brief tour we were ushered into the tasting room where we were offered a cup of tea.  She stood over us (more like hovered)as we sipped our tea and then followed us into the shop never more than a few steps behind.  It felt quite uncomfortable.....to the point where we simply wanted to leave even though we were planning on buying some tea.   Sorry Glenloch...we had hoped for a better experience.

I love tea, so I was always going to visit A tea factory.  I understand they're all pretty much of a muchness, all similarly styled from the colonial days of past.  The walk around with an attractive and good English speaking female talked us through the tea making process from the leaf picking to the sorting, drying, crushing, dividing, bagging of the leaves. All looks archaic but it seems to do the trick and they produce and export an enormous quantity per day, so very impressive.  You then get a taste of 3 teas, black, green & white - all good then you can buy loose or bags.  I must say we did buy some green tea and now home can taste the difference to what I've bought in supermarkets.  What they don't show you are the fields and pickers, but you do have the benefit of seeing these lush fields on steep hills on the route into the plantations.  Looks like incredibly hard work but the Sri Lankan people are generous with their smiles so go ahead and visit if you have time.

Factory guide girls are really friendly you can find a guide who can speak your language. They explain it very well. And also tea here is upto the standard. You can taste different types of tea free of charge. I take my clients to this place as the first stop on the way to Nuwara eliya from Kandy.
It's a must to visit a tea factory during travelling through Sri Lanka. We had a short guided tour in the factory which was interesting. Good for buying some gifts for people at home,
